Heterogeneous sequential N-arylation of N-heterocycles over copper anchored mesoporous silica catalyst Soma Das Tanmoy Maity Subratanath Koner â Department of Chemistry, Jadavpur University, Jadavpur, Kolkata 700 032, India Department of Chemistry Jadavpur University Jadavpur Kolkata 700 032 India â Corresponding author. Fax: +91 33 2414 6414. Graphical abstract N-Arylation reaction of N-heterocyclic compounds has been carried out in excellent yield using copper anchored SBA-15 catalyst. Sequential N-arylation reactions employing single catalyst under heterogeneous condition provides a straightforward access to a series of important arylazolium salts. Simplicity of the method and outstanding character of the catalyst facilitate the reactions to go smoothly which encompass a broad range of functional groups. Catalyst can be recovered and reused several times without any significant loss in its catalytic activity. Keywords Copper Schiff-base Heterogeneous catalyst Mesoporous SBA-15 Heterocyclic N-arylation Aryl quaternization 1 Introduction Copper catalyzed N-arylation of nitrogen containing heterocycles via the classical Ullmann-type coupling had widely been reported in the literature [1â6]. However further Nâ²-arylation of N-arylazoles without acidic proton which affords quaternized salt has been attempted scarcely [7â12]. Quaternized salts are used as important precursor of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) [8], anion receptors [13], fluorophores [14] etc. Various protocols have been applied for quaternization of N-arylazoles which includes direct aryl quaternization of N-substituted imidazoles catalyzed by copper(II) salt in homogeneous medium [7â10]. Nevertheless ligands which afford electron-rich metal complexes with increased stability can be a viable strategy to circumvent catalyst deterioration. Such systems are necessary to reach a high degree of efficiency and/or selectivity [15]. Even though homogeneous catalytic systems are known to exhibit better reactivity than heterogeneous systems, for large-scale liquid-phase reactions, heterogeneous catalyst is highly desirable because of ease of handling, simple recovery/recycling of the catalyst and minimization of unnecessary toxic wastes [16]. Furthermore, designing of heterogeneous catalytic system with comparable efficiency to that of homogeneous catalyst is a challenge. To our knowledge there is hardly any report of metal complex based heterogeneous catalyst for synthesis of arylazolium salts. Hence, we have endeavored to search a suitable heterogeneous system in this study in respect of its practical application. Schiff-base transition metal complexes had been studied widely due to their potential application in catalyzing various catalytic reactions [17,18]. Ease of loading of Schiff-base moiety onto the solids supports such as resins [19], alumina [20], zeolites [21], porous silicas [22] through heterogenization [23], encapsulation or post-synthesis modification [24] paved the way for designing of hybrid catalysts. However, there are certain disadvantages with polymeric supports and zeolites owing to their vulnerability towards some chemicals/solvents, pore size restriction and severe leaching of metals [25]. Conversely large pore mesoporous silica SBA-15, with larger surface area [26] and higher stability owing to thicker walls in comparison to MCM-41 [27], is considered to be good candidate for catalytic support [28]. In addition large pore size facilitates easy diffusion of bulky reactants and products during catalytic reactions [29]. We report herein, for the first time, a heterogeneous copper Schiff-base modified SBA-15 catalyst, S(C)-15 (see Section 2) for sequential N-arylation reactions producing some new arylazolium salts. Single catalyst can be employed for CN cross-coupling reaction between aryl halides and N-heterocyclic compounds (imidazoles, bezimidazoles, triazoles) and successively Nâ²-arylation of those N-arylazoles by using diphenyliodonium tetrafluoroborate salt under leaching free condition. To compare the catalytic efficacy of heterogeneous catalyst, S(C)-15 with an analogous homogeneous system, a copper(II) Schiff-base complex 1 (see Section 2) with similar active center configuration has been designed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O, tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), the non-ionic surfactant Pluronic P123, 3-((2-aminoethylamino)propyl)-trimethoxysilane (ATMS), N-(N-propyl)ethylenediamine, o-hydroxyacetophenone and all other reagents were purchased either from SigmaâAldrich/Fluka or Alfa-Aesar and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purchased from Merck (India) and were distilled and dried before use. 2.2 Physical measurements Mesoporous materials were characterized by small angle powdered X-ray (SAX) diffraction study. Small angle X-ray patterns of all powdered samples were taken in the 2Î¸ range of 2â10Â° at a rate of 2Â°minâ1 in steps of 0.02Â° (Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer) using Cu-KÎ± radiation. Powder X-ray patterns of complex 1 were taken in the 2Î¸ range of 5â50Â°. PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer was used to microanalysis of samples (C, H and N). IR spectra (KBr pellet) were measured on a PerkinElmer L1600300 FTIR spectrometer. The solid state diffuse reflectance UVâvis spectra were recorded by UV-2401 PC SHIMADZU spectrophotometer. EPR spectra of the catalyst and complex 1 were collected from JEOL JES-FA200 ESR spectrometer. The copper content of catalyst was determined by a PerkinElmer A-Analyst 200 atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS). BET surface area and total pore volume of the mesoporous samples were determined by an Autosorb-iQ (Quantachorme Inc.) gas sorption system. Prior to analyses, all the samples were degassed at 130Â°C under vacuum until a final pressure of 10â2 Torr was reached to evacuate the physically adsorbed moisture. The transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of samples was obtained on a JEOL-TEM-2010 electron microscopes with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images were recorded on ZEISS EVO 18 (Special edition) and energy dispersive X-ray scattering (EDS) analysis of samples (with gold coating) was done on OXFORD EDS8100 equipment. TG/DTA thermograms were recorded on a PerkinElmer (Singapore) Pyris Diamond TG/DTA unit with N2 carrier gas flowing at a rate of 150mLminâ1 and the heating rate was programmed at 4Â°Cminâ1. All products of the catalytic reactions were collected and purified by column chromatographic method and characterized by elemental analysis and comparing of their NMR and Mass spectra with the literature data. Reactions were monitored by TLC and NMR spectra recorded in CDCl3 or in DMSO-d6 on a Bruker Avance DPX 300 NMR (300MHz) spectrometer. Mass spectra were measured on a Waters XEVO-G2QTOF#YCA351 high resolution mass spectrometer. 2.3 Synthesis of heterogeneous catalyst S(C)-15 Mesoporous silica material, SBA-15 was synthesized by following the procedure described in literature [30]. In a typical experiment (see Scheme S1), SBAâ15 (calcined, 0.1g), dry chloroform (12mL) and ATMS (0.1mL, 0.46mmol) was stirred at room temperature for 12h under N2 atmosphere. The white solid thus formed, named S(A)-15, was filtered, washed with dry chloroform for several times followed by dry dichloromethane and dried in air. This solid was then refluxed with o-hydroxyacetophenone (0.063g, 0.46mmol) in methanol (12mL) for 6h at 65Â°C in air. The resulting yellowish solid, S(SB)-15 was then collected by filtration and was dried in a desiccator. Finally, the S(C)-15 was prepared by refluxing S(SB)-15 with Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O (0.09g, 0.46mmol) in methanol (12mL) at 65Â°C for 12h under air. The green solid thus formed was filtered, washed with methanol using a Soxhlet, and dried under vacuum. The Cu content (measured from AAS) of the catalyst found to be 1.5 (wt.%) (0.02mol.%). Elemental analysis showed Cu:N was 2.05. 2.4 Synthesis of copper(II) Schiff-base complex 1 As shown in Scheme S2, the Schiff-base, HL was synthesized by refluxing equimolar mixture of N-(N-propyl) ethylenediamine (0.102g, 1.0mmol) and o-hydroxyacetophenone (0.136g, 1.0mmol) in methanol. Consecutively a solution of Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O (0.199g,1.0mmol) in methanol was added to the Schiff-base solution and stirred for few minutes. The resulted green solution was kept for slow evaporation process. After several days single green colored block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. The Cu content (measured from AAS) of the catalyst found to be 6.2 (wt%) (0.1mol.%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C15H24CuN2O4: C 50.06, H 6.72, N 7.78; found: C 50.0, H 6.7, N 7.8. 2.5 General experimental procedure for the N-arylation reactions A mixture of aryl halide (2.4mmol) and Cs2CO3 (4.0mmol, 0.650g), nitrogen-containing heterocycle (2.0mmol), dry DMF (3mL) solvent and catalyst was stirred at 100Â°C in an oil bath under air. After cooling to room temperature, catalyst was first separated out by centrifugation and the liquid part was extracted with water and diethylether (2Ã15mL). The organic layers thus collected were combined and washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (mesh 60â120) using an n-hexane/ethylacetate mixture as the eluent to collect the desired product. The product was analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR and mass spectroscopy. 2.6 General experimental procedure for the quaternization of N-arylated compounds At first diphenyliodonium tetrafluoroborate was synthesized according to procedure reported previously [31] and characterized by 1H and 13C NMR and mass spectral analysis (see Supplementary content). A mixture of N-heteroarene (1.0mmol), diphenyliodonium salt (1.5mmol), catalyst and DMF (3mL) was stirred at 80Â°C for a desired time in air. After cooled down to room temperature, heterogeneous catalyst was separated out by centrifugation. The liquid part was then subjected to rotary evaporation and the residue obtained was passed through a silica gel column (dichloromethane/acetone=5:1â2:1 v/v) to afford the desired arylazolium salt. The product was analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR and mass spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Small angle X-ray diffraction patterns of SBA-15, S(SB)-15 and S(C)-15 are shown in Fig. 1 . Pattern of fresh SBA-15 demonstrated typical three diffraction lines [32] with a very strong d 100 =101.32Ã diffraction line at 2Î¸ â0.88Ã and two small diffraction lines for the 110 and 200 planes at 2Î¸ â1.46Ã and 2Î¸ â1.68Ã, respectively confirming a well defined P 6mm hexagonal symmetry and long-range ordering of structure [33]. Like the parent material SBA-15, all modified porous samples S(SB)-15 and S(C)-15 showed the similar diffraction patterns indicating the chemical process involved in modification of mesoporous silica did not diminish the structural ordering of the SBA-15, however, some degree of decrease in crystallinity takes place in the catalyst. A progressive decrease in the intensity and shifting of the peaks towards the higher angle was observed after the sequential modification of the pore of SBA-15. The intensity reduction may be mainly due to contrast matching between the silicate framework and organic moieties present in the channels of SBA-15 [25]. FTIR spectra of S(SB)-15 and S(C)-15 are shown in Fig. 2 A. Schiff-base functionalized SBA-15 (Fig. 2Aa) showed a peak at 1618cmâ1 which may assign to the CN stretching frequency of the CN imine bond. A shift of ca. 14cmâ1 in imine CN stretching towards lower frequency region was observed upon metalation (Fig. 2Ab) indicating the coordination of azo-methaine nitrogen to the copper ion. Besides, there were asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of acetate group typical for bridged acetate at â¼1561cmâ1 and â¼1440cmâ1, respectively [18]. While in complex 1 azomethine stretch appeared at â¼1598cmâ1 and acetate vibrations appeared at â¼1549cmâ1 and 1440cmâ1 (Fig. 2B) suggesting the formation of metal complex moiety with similar configuration in S(C)-15. The solid state diffuse reflectance UVâvis spectrum of S(SB)-15 showed four absorption maxima at ca. 215, 250, 319 and 387nm (Fig. 3 Aa) which could be attributed to intra ligand charge transfer transitions. A similar spectrum was obtained for HL as shown in Fig. 3Ab. Upon complex formation intra ligand charge transfer bands shifted towards higher wavelength region and a new band at ca. 642nm appeared which can be attributed to dâd transition (Fig. 3Bb). A similar type of shifting was also observed in case of S(C)-15 and an expected new band dâd transitions band at â¼644nm indicating similar type of coordination environment of copper(II) Schiff-base moiety in SBA-15 (Fig. 3Ba) as is exhibited in complex 1. The X-band EPR spectra were measured at room temperature for both catalyst S(C)-15 and complex 1 and are shown in Fig. 4 A and B, respectively. Both S(C)-15 and 1 feature g ÇÇ > g â¥ >2.0023 (Table S4) which clearly suggest the characteristic of square planar geometry in copper(II) complexes [34]. Comparable g values and similarity of EPR spectrum also suggest the presence of similar type of ligand environment around copper(II) center in S(C)-15 and complex 1. N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution plots for SBA-15, S(SB)-15 and S(C)-15 are displayed in Fig. 5 A and B respectively. All plots are of typical of type IV isotherm (according to the IUPAC nomenclature), with hysteresis loops, which is characteristic of the mesoporous materials. A gradual decrease in the BET surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter could be observed at each stage of modification as expected because the organic fragments or metal complexes are entering into the channels. Nitrogen sorption study exhibits that the BET surface area of SBA-15 is 1882m2 gâ1 while the mesopore volume is 2.589cm3 gâ1. The average pore diameter is calculated to be 31.132Ã using the NLDFT method (Table S5). All calculated values are in agreement with those reported for good-quality mesoporous silica. S(SB)-15 shows lower N2 uptake, smaller pore volume and pore diameter whereas the S(C)-15 catalyst shows even lower N2 uptake, and smaller pore volume and pore diameter (Table S5). As the pores become bulkier, hysteresis occurs at lower P/P 0 with a concomitant decrease in pore size [35]. This indicates that the immobilization of the copper(II) complex has taken place substantially inside the pore channels of SBA-15. This kind of reduction in surface area, pore volume and pore diameter was also reported in the literature [25]. To assess the mesoporosity of SBA-15 and catalyst, samples were studied with TEM analysis. Fig. 6 shows top view and a cross-section of the pore system. Both the SBA-15 matrix and catalyst showed an open-ended lamellar type morphology (Fig. 6a and c) and honeycomb-like hexagonal arrangements (Fig. 6b and d) as confirmed by Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) pattern (inset of Fig. 6b and d). When electron beam falls on the catalyst perpendicular to the pore axis, the pores are seen to be arranged in patches composed of regular rows, as has been interpreted by Chenite et al. [36]. TEM micrograph of SBA-15 viewed along the pore axis reveals a hexagonal array having a channel dimension of â¼9.7nm, which is consistent with the XRD results. S(C)-15 also exhibits a similar type of array of regular rows in TEM micrographs. Therefore, it can be concluded that both SBA-15 and S(C)-15 have a similar type of external morphology. In our case, the morphology of the tubules in SBA-15 and in S(C)-15 is rectilinear. The TEM image provides strong evidence that the long-range ordering of the support framework is retained even after the immobilization of the copper(II) Schiff base complex in the mesoporous silica matrix. Therefore, it can be concluded that SBA-15 preserves its morphology up to formation of catalyst even after withstanding all the reaction steps starting from the pore functionalization to the binding of CuII. SEM images were captured for the mesoporous samples (Fig. 7 A). All SEM images revealed the similar worm-like morphology typical for SBA type mesoporous materials [37]. This also suggest that no significant changes of the external surface morphology occurred upon inclusion of Schiff-base of the copper(II) complex into SBA-15. EDS elemental analysis (Fig. 7B) indicates the presence of copper and nitrogen in the catalyst whereas these atoms were absent in SBA-15. 3.2 Catalytic activity In order to get optimal conditions for CN cross coupling reaction we first examined the influences of different parameters e.g., solvent, base, reaction temperature,% Cu loading in catalyst, reaction time etc. These parameters can influence the progress on CN cross coupling reaction [38]. Our objective was to develop a protocol that requires minimum amount of catalyst for smooth CN cross coupling reaction and that tolerate a wide range of functional groups on both coupling partners. We first screen the optimized conditions for reaction of imidazole with p-bromonitrobenzene and the results are summarized in Table S6. As the catalyst is thermal and air stable, inert atmosphere was not employed. It is noteworthy that the coupling reaction does not proceed without copper catalyst (Table S6, entry 3). Of the different solvents investigated, DMF was the most suited for catalytic reaction (Table S6, entry 1). While finding out the suitable base for coupling reaction it is noticed that the performance of insoluble inorganic bases, such as K2CO3, K3PO4, Cs2CO3, Na2CO3, and Na3PO4 were much better in comparison to soluble organic base like Et3N (Table S6, entries 1â11). Notably, when fine powdered Cs2CO3 was used, excellent arylated product was obtained (Table S6, entries 1 and 2) due to the enhanced basicity of Cs2CO3 [39]. Reaction temperature and time also has great impact on N-arylation of imidazole. Reaction at 60Â°C produced low yield (Table S6, entry 13) even after 30h. With increase of temperature yield increased and gave a maximum of product yield at 100Â°C whereas upon further increase in temperature yield decreased gradually. This is due to formation of some unwanted non-isolated by-products (Table S6, entry 14). Generally, aryl iodide shows greater reactivity than aryl bromide in the cross-coupling reactions. However, in present case both aryl iodide and aryl bromide (Table S6, entries 1 and 15) showed comparable yields. In a recent study, it had been proposed that the Iâ or I2 generated from iodobenzene can act as an inhibitor during the catalytic process [40]. Thus the optimized reaction conditions were found to be Cs2CO3 (as the base) and DMF (as the solvent) at 100Â°C under air. To study the catalytic efficacy of S(C)-15, we controlled the copper loading in the catalyst by varying the amount of Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O in the Schiff-base complex formation as shown in Fig. S1 (see Supplementary content). With the optimal condition in hand we examined reaction of various N-heterocyclic amines with bromobenzenes containing diverse functional groups. Evidently the reaction tolerates varieties of functional groups. p-Nitrobromobenzene delivered an excellent yield showing a TOF value 165hâ1 while o-nitrobromobenzene also gives comparable yield (Table 1 , entries 1 and 2). It was observed that bromoarenes containing electron-withdrawing groups reacted at a faster rate and affords higher yield than bromoarenes with electron-donating substitution groups (Table 1, entries 9 and 10). Benzimidazole and triazoles reacted fairly well with substituted bromobenzenes to give the corresponding N-arylated products in good yield (Table 1, entries 6â15). Benzimidazole showed a little difficulty to react with arylbromide compared to imidazole indicating the sensitivity of reaction towards steric hindrance of the nucleophiles (Table 1, entries 1 and 7). After successful demonstration of the insertion of aryl groups into imidazole via CN cross coupling, we tried to incorporate another aryl group in N-substituted imidazoles using same catalyst which yielded quaternized salt of imidazoles. In the standardization process we started by reacting N-p-nitrophenylimidazole with diphenyliodonium salts in different solvents at different temperature. Reaction does not proceed without employing copper catalyst (Table S7, entry 1). Reaction in acetonitrile, DMSO, toluene or dioxane afforded lower yields than in DMF (Table S7, entries 7â10). Changing Ph2IBF4 with Ph2ICl keeping other reaction condition unaltered produced negative result (Table S7, entry 6). However, lowering of temperature to 80Â°C the catalyst showed excellent activity in DMF with 95% yield in open atmosphere (Table S7, entry 11). Evidently we were succeeded in inserting subsequent aryl group into N-arylazoles to synthesize an array of unsymmetrical N,Nâ²-diarylatedimidazolium compounds under the optimized reaction condition and the results are summarized in Table 2 . N-p-Nitrophenylimidazole showed excellent activity to afford the corresponding quaternized salt within 6h (Table 2, entries 1) with a TOF value of 158hâ1. Nevertheless, o-nitro variety showed a comparable yield with more or less equal value of TOF (Table 2, entries 2). Other substituents such as cyano, bromo at different positions of the phenyl ring were also successfully Nâ²-arylated to afford the corresponding unsymmetrical imidazolium salts in high yields (Table 2, entries 3â5). N-Arylated benzimidazoles gave moderate to high yield within 6h (Table 2, entries 7â10). It was found that electron-donating substituents yielded less compared to electron-withdrawing substituents while non-substituted benzimidazole demonstrates a middling yield (Table 2, entries 6â10). Between N-arylated 1,2,3-triazoles and 1,2,4-triazoles later showed more product selectivity (Table 2, entries 11â15). To ascertain the catalytic efficiency of S(C)-15 we have undertaken few control experiments. It is known that Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O catalyzes aryl quarternization reaction efficiently [7,8]. Cu(OAc)2Â·H2O catalyzed the reaction between N-p-nitrophenylimidazole and diphenyliodonium salt in DMF at 100Â°C (Table S7, entry 2) showing a TOF value of ca. 1.92hâ1. In contrast the catalyst S(C)-15 efficiently catalyzed the same reaction at much lower temperature (at 80Â°C). Though S(C)-15 requires little longer time to complete the reaction, the TOF of the reaction exceeds 158hâ1. For a similar set of catalysts and catalyzed reactions generally homogeneous system performed better than its corresponding heterogeneous counterpart. With this view we have prepared complex 1 to compare the activity of copper center in homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions. Coupling of N-p-nitrophenylimidazole and diphenyliodonium salt can be catalyzed by complex 1 under homogeneous condition in shorter period of time (Table S7, entry 3). 3.3 Hot filtration test To ascertain the catalysis is indeed heterogeneous we have performed hot filtration test (see Supplementary content) [38]. Liquid phase of the reaction mixture was collected by filtration at the reaction temperature when the catalytic reaction (both for N-arylation and quaternization) was 30% complete and the residual activity of the supernatant solution was studied. Coupling reactions do not proceed further after filtration of catalyst (Fig. S2). Atomic absorption spectrometric analysis (sensitivity up to 0.001ppm) of the supernatant solution collected by filtration also confirmed the absence of copper in the liquid phase for both the cases. The above results suggest that Cu was not being leached out from the solid catalyst during the reactions. 3.4 Three phase test To get deeper insight into the heterogeneity of the system, we performed three phase tests [38]. for N-arylation reaction using a designed aryl halide in usual condition as described in Scheme S4 (see supplementary content). In the case of the solid phase immobilized aryl bromide, no reaction was observed on support even after 12h at 100Â°C and no N-p-acetylphenylimidazole was detected. We found p-bromoacetophenone remained unreacted, while the soluble p-bromonitrobenzene substrate converted to N-p-nitrophenylimidazole as expected for N-arylation reaction. If there were any leaching of Cu from the catalyst, solid phase anchored p-bromoacetophenone would have also participated in the above-described reactions. However, this has not happened for the present catalyst. Therefore, all the above tests convincingly demonstrate that there was no leaching of Cu species occurring in the S(C)-15 catalyzed N-arylation reactions. 3.5 Separation and catalyst reuse For recycling study the first N-arylation reactions were performed with p-bromonitrobenzene, imidazole and Cs2CO3 (Table 1, entry 1), maintaining the optimized reaction conditions. For quaternization we used N-p-nitrophenylimidazole and diphenyliodoniun tetrafluoroborate maintaining the same reaction condition (Table 2, entry 1). As 5mg of solid catalyst was not enough to recover, reuse and finally characterize, therefore, catalyst was collected from different batches of same catalytic cycle and an average values were given here. After the every cycle, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and then washed thoroughly with (9:1) acetonitrileâwater mixture. The recovered catalyst was dried under vacuum at 100Â°C overnight. Atomic absorption spectrometric analysis of the recovered catalysts from both reactions confirmed the copper content of the S(C)-15 remained virtually the same. The performance of the recycled catalyst up to five successive runs is shown in Fig. 8 . In order to check the stability of the recovered catalyst, it was thoroughly characterized by X-ray powder diffraction, gas adsorption study and SEM image. Comparison of powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Fig. S3), gas adsorption studies (Fig. S4), transmission electron microscopic measurement (Fig. S5) and SEM images (Fig. S6) of the pristine and recovered catalyst convincingly demonstrated that the structural integrity of the catalysts retained after reaction. TEM images of the recovered catalyst showed no sign of formation of Cu nanoparticles on the surface of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary we have successfully developed a novel heterogeneous catalyst for synthesis of some important unsymmetrical N,Nâ²-diarylated imidazolium compounds via a facile procedure. Single catalyst can activate consecutively two step of N- and Nâ²-arylation of imidazoles and some of its congeners. Simplicity of the method and outstanding character of the catalyst facilitates the reaction to go smoothly encompassing a broad range of functional groups. The catalyst is resistant to leaching under the reaction condition. Both the arylation can be undertaken in open flask reaction which makes the procedures easily accessible for synthesis of a variety of important compounds. coredata.dc:description: N-Arylation reaction of N-heterocyclic compounds has been carried out in excellent yield using copper anchored SBA-15 catalyst. Sequential N-arylation reactions employing single catalyst under heterogeneous condition provides a straightforward access to a series of important arylazolium salts. Simplicity of the method and outstanding character of the catalyst facilitate the reactions to go smoothly which encompass a broad range of functional groups. Catalyst can be recovered and reused several times without any significant loss in its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous sequential N-arylation of N-heterocycles over copper anchored mesoporous silica catalyst
